author: By Melissa Clark
title: The Best Butterscotch Pudding Is Homemade
description: This unfussy, old-fashioned recipe is easy to stir together on top of the stove, and hard to mess up.
content: There was a time in my life when I made a stand for custard over pudding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Bruno Fernandes and the Long Game
description: The Portuguese midfielder’s circuitous path to Manchester United stardom revealed inefficiencies in soccer’s vast scouting system, and how even a sure thing can almost slip through the cracks.
content: MANCHESTER, England — What strikes Martelinho, whenever he watches Bruno Fernandes play, is how little he has changed. Fernandes might now be the best player on the in-form team in the world’s biggest league, but to Martelinho, he is not recognizably different from the teenager he coached in the youth teams of a struggling Portuguese club a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Jets Hire Robert Saleh of the 49ers as Head Coach
description: Saleh, believed to be the first Muslim Arab American head coach in the N.F.L., will take over the franchise with the league’s longest current postseason drought.
content: The Jets have reached an agreement for Robert Saleh, the defensive coordinator of the San Francisco 49ers, to become their next head coach, the team announced Thursday, and — if all goes well — to lead the team out of a stupor that has left it without a postseason appearance for the past decade and as the butt of a running joke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart
title: Why Are There So Few Courageous Senators?
description: Here’s what we need to do if we want more Mitt Romneys and fewer Josh Hawleys.
content: Now that Donald Trump has been defanged, leading Republicans are rushing to denounce him. It’s a little late. The circumstances were different then, but a year ago, only one Republican senator, Mitt Romney, backed impeachment. In a party that has been largely servile, Mr. Romney’s courage stands out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: A Well-Planned Date That Sealed the Deal and Inspired an App
description: Jordan Scott was not impressed when she first met Nick Gash at a dive bar in New York. But his thoughtfully curated “48-hour” first date changed her mind.
content: The 14 guests who sent screen shots of negative Covid tests to Jordan Scott and Nick Gash before their New Year’s Eve wedding did so out of devotion to a couple whose love felt worth leaving home for amid a pandemic. But they couldn’t have been blamed for expecting to attend a more action-packed celebration than normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: David Barclay, Reclusive British Business Mogul, Dies at 86
description: With his twin brother, Frederick, he built a media and business empire that included the Ritz Hotel in London and The Daily Telegraph.
content: David Barclay, a British billionaire who with his twin brother, Frederick, built a media and business empire that includes the influential conservative newspaper The Daily Telegraph, died on Sunday. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Sincere, Outdoorsy, Trippy, a Music Festival Breathes Los Angeles
description: Darkness Sounding, a solstice-inspired embrace “of the body and for the body,” is coming from the group Wild Up.
content: Answering the phone and having the person on the other end sing softly for 10 minutes, just for you. Another vocalist, this one stationed outside your house for a five-minute concert. A piano recital stretching from dawn to dusk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: In Robert Saleh, the Jets Believe They Found the Leader They Need
description: Saleh’s defense carried the San Francisco 49ers to a Super Bowl appearance. But it was his ability to motivate players that brought him to New York.
content: Robert Saleh oversaw a San Francisco 49ers defense that came within minutes of winning the Super Bowl last year and that managed to rank among the league’s best this season despite missing many of its top players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman
title: She Killed an American in 2012. Why Was She Freed in the Taliban Deal?
description: The internal debate in Washington over the fate of an Iranian prisoner in Afghanistan illustrates one of the difficult decisions the end of a war brings.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Nargis Mohammad Hasan was serving as an Afghan police officer when she shot and killed an American civilian adviser on Dec. 24, 2012, in Afghanistan’s capital. It was considered the first known attack by a woman in the Afghan security forces on a coalition member since the U.S. invasion in 2001.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luca Powell
title: ‘It’s Starting Again’: Why Filipino Nurses Dread the Second Wave
description: Indispensable to New York City hospitals, health care workers from the Philippines died in shocking numbers last spring. Will things be different this winter?
content: Belinda Ellis had been a nurse for 40 years, and she thought she’d seen it all. She had worked in hospitals in the Philippines, where she was born and got her degree. She was a nurse in Saudi Arabia and then at a military hospital on the border of Iraq when Saddam Hussein came into power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: As Washington and several states brace for unrest, Biden reveals his vaccine and economic plans.
description: As the fallout from the assault on the Capitol sparks fresh concerns of new violence and Washington heightens security ahead of Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inauguration on Jan. 20, the president-elect is gearing up to assume office at a tenuous moment for the nation.
content: As the fallout from the assault on the Capitol sparks fresh concerns of new violence and Washington heightens security ahead of Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s inauguration on Jan. 20, the president-elect is gearing up to assume office at a tenuous moment for the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Make Meatballs
description: Triple a batch of Kay Chun’s pork and ricotta meatballs, and build meals around them for days.
content: Hello and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. As we plod through these first few weeks of 2021, I felt the best thing I could do for you was to tell you to make meatballs — lots of meatballs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Vespoli
title: ‘I Literally Had No One.’ Then the Foster Kittens Arrived.
description: The pandemic has made life hard for many people, and their pets, but others find themselves with more time and the resources to help.
content: Last summer, Jali Henry was feeling lonely and depressed after many of her friends moved out of the city because of the pandemic. “I literally had no one,” she said. “I was like, ‘What the hell am I doing here?’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disneyland ends annual passes, citing uncertainty around the pandemic.
description: The program is ending in part because Disney expects pent-up demand to far outstrip capacity when the resort eventually reopens.
content: Disneyland, which has been closed for 10 months because of California’s strict approach to coronavirus safety, alerted annual passholders that it was ending the popular program, which it started offering to hard-core customers in the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Big Tech Has Helped Trash America
description: The chaos of the last two weeks offers an opportunity to rethink the role of technology in our lives.
content: Of all the myths we have about America, perhaps the most potent one is found in the age-old question we constantly ask ourselves as a nation: Can we start over?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: ‘Stop the Steal’ Didn’t Start With Trump
description: Mainstream Republicans and conservative commentators have been pushing the idea that Democrats can only win through fraud for decades.
content: To explain the attack on the Capitol, you can’t just turn your focus to Donald Trump and his enablers. You must also look at the individuals and institutions that fanned fears of “voter fraud” to the point of hysteria among conservative voters, long before Trump. Put another way, the difference between a riot seeking to overturn an election and an effort to suppress opposing votes is one of legality, not intent. And it doesn’t take many steps to get from one to the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night: Shocker. Trump Stiffs Giuliani and Won’t Take His Calls.
description: “Impeachment was great, but there really is no more perfect way for this to end than Trump stiffing Rudy,” Seth Meyers said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: The Filmmaker as Historian: Sam Pollard and ‘MLK/FBI’
description: Whether working on his own projects or others like “Eyes on the Prize II” and “4 Little Girls,” the multihyphenate artist has built a monumental career examining America.
content: Midway through the new documentary “MLK/FBI,” we get glimpses of a Martin Luther King Jr. not often seen in the usual montages of the civil rights movement. The 1963 March on Washington has taken place and he has accepted the Nobel Peace Prize. This King is under myriad strains from the burdens of leadership, budding concerns about Vietnam, political and mortal threats, and round-the-clock surveillance by his own country’s chief law enforcement agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: How the New Variant Could Affect Kids and Schools
description: It is expected to become the dominant form of the coronavirus by March in the United States.
content: A new variant of the coronavirus, first identified in Britain, is expected to rapidly spread in the United States. That has fueled fears that children, who have largely been spared the worst of the virus, may become just as susceptible and contagious as adults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: A Second Economic Crisis for Biden, but a Different First Response
description: The president-elect’s proposed economic rescue package is larger and more targeted to the country’s needs than the stimulus plan he helped steer into law as vice president in 2009.
content: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr. is inheriting an economic crisis as he assumes the presidency, just as he did when he became vice president a dozen years ago. But this crisis is different and, to the relief of many liberal economists, so is Mr. Biden’s response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: Can a Strained Marriage Survive Confinement?
description: And, how a flawed first impression led to an epic first date.
content: For some married couples, the stress of quarantine and trying to create normalcy in confined spaces have led to bubbling tensions and arguments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: M.T.A. Bus Plunges 50 Feet, Dangles From Overpass After Crash
description: Eight people, including the driver, were injured when the front of the bus spilled onto the Cross Bronx Expressway, officials said.
content: The images seemed like something out of a movie: an articulated public bus dangling over a highway overpass in the Bronx, passengers trapped inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: With Vaccines and Stimulus on the Way, Banks Brighten Their Outlook
description: The biggest banks in the United States have begun to pare back the enormous reserves they had socked away in case of an economic disaster.
content: Optimism is taking hold among the country’s largest banks.With the rollout of vaccines underway and a new round of economic stimulus landing soon, JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup each said on Friday that they had begun to pare back the enormous reserves they had socked away in case of an economic disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Lauren Wolfe
title: There have now been over two million virus-related deaths worldwide.
description: A year into the pandemic, the carnage is spreading faster than ever.
content: Two million dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: After Frosty Houston Split, Harden Says He’s an ‘Elite Teammate’
description: James Harden, who was traded to the Nets this week, had been called “disrespectful” by his former teammates in Houston, who he said were “not good enough” to win a championship.
content: Days after telling reporters he did not think the Houston Rockets were talented enough to be competitive, James Harden said on Friday that he is an “elite player, an elite teammate” and an “elite leader,” in his first comments as a member of the Nets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Does a Woman ‘Walking’ Her Boyfriend on a Leash Signal Covid Ennui?
description: Coronavirus restrictions across Canada, including a new curfew in Quebec, are fraying patience and spurring protests in some quarters.
content: Last Saturday at 9 p.m., as residents across Quebec sat indoors to obey a new pandemic curfew, the police patrolling the sleepy city of Sherbrooke observed a perhaps unlikely crime: a woman “walking” her boyfriend, attached to a leash, as he padded along the sidewalk on all fours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Kevin Armstrong
title: Smokers in N.J. Are Eligible for Vaccine. No Proof Needed.
description: New Jersey is one of only two states that has included smoking among the high-risk medical conditions that make people eligible for the Covid-19 vaccine.
content: Faced with soaring rates of coronavirus infection and more doses of vaccine in freezers than in arms, New Jersey officials made a calculated choice.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The View From a Republican Who Voted to Impeach
description: Representative Peter Meijer of Michigan explains why he joined nine colleagues in breaking from his party.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: The Big Promises Biden Is Making
description: The president-elect signals an aggressive economic agenda: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Biden asks Americans to “imagine a future” beyond the virus, pushing a $1.9 trillion plan to promote jobs and prosperity. It’s Friday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliana Kim
title: The Vaccine Hurdles Older New Yorkers Face
description: Making an inoculation appointment has been a challenge, with crashing websites, confusing sign-up systems and a shortage of openings.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fleur Macdonald
title: What, if Anything, Can Psychics Tell Us About All of This?
description: Demand for their services has illuminated another kind of health crisis.
content: A few weeks before the U.S. presidential election, Zulema Hormaeche, a tarot reader in Los Angeles, chose a card to reflect the state of the nation. It was the one that depicts a tall building struck by lightning, with flames bursting from the top and occupants leaping to their deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: Speed Up Vaccinations and Reduce the Red Tape
description: Punitive efforts to ensure strict adherence to complicated eligibility rules endangers people who could be protected.
content: The debate goes on over the best vaccination strategy. Is it better to prioritize by age, since the disease is far more likely to seriously harm older people? How about essential workers — many of whom are poor people of color — since they suffer strikingly high rates of illness and death? Should everyone who works at a hospital be vaccinated, even those with no patient contact? And so on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Katie Benner
title: Inaugural Security Is Fortified in D.C. as Military and Police Links Are Eyed in Riot
description: Dozens of people in Washington on the day of the attack on the Capitol were said to be on a terrorism watch list.
content: Thousands of armed National Guard troops were on their way to Washington to bolster security for next week’s inaugural celebration as federal investigators turned their attention to the difficult question of how many military and police personnel took part in the violent attack on the Capitol, a law enforcement official said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Bruce Springsteen and John Legend to Perform at Biden Inauguration Event
description: Foo Fighters, Eva Longoria and Kerry Washington will also take part in the prime-time television special.
content: Bruce Springsteen, John Legend and Foo Fighters will perform during the prime-time special that will cap the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., and the actors Eva Longoria and Kerry Washington will also have roles to play in the program, the Presidential Inaugural Committee said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: U.S. Figure Skating to Pay $1.45 Million to Ex-Skater Who Says He Was Abused
description: Adam Schmidt had accused U.S. Figure Skating, the sport’s national governing body, of failing to protect him from sexual abuse by Richard Callaghan, a once-prominent coach of Olympians.
content: U.S. Figure Skating has reached a $1.45 million settlement with a former skater who had accused the organization of failing to protect him from sexual abuse by Richard Callaghan, a once-prominent coach of Olympians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Glenn Thrush
title: Federal watchdogs open a far-reaching investigation into failures in the lead-up to the Capitol riot.
description: Inspectors general from a range of federal agencies are opening a coordinated investigation into the catastrophic failures that led to the riot at the Capitol on Jan. 6.
content: Inspectors general from a range of federal agencies are opening a coordinated investigation into the catastrophic failures that led to the riot at the Capitol on Jan. 6, amid reports that officials ignored, downplayed and responded sluggishly to a deadly assault on the nation’s core democratic institutions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: Survey Finds Majority of Voters Support Initiatives to Fight Climate Change
description: A survey carried out after the November election found that 66 percent of respondents said that developing sources of clean energy should be a high or very high priority.
content: A majority of registered voters of both parties in the United States support initiatives to fight climate change, including many that are outlined in the climate plans announced by President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., according to a new survey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Court Stroud
title: The Grizzly in the Purple Pants
description: My mom and stepdad wanted me to be more manly. In Cub Scouts, I just wanted to make the troop cupcakes.
content: Russell Lee spat a wad of snuff into a Planters peanuts can. We sat at a picnic table in his backyard, next to the railroad tracks. He jackhammered the ground with his right leg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geraldine Fabrikant
title: With Vaccines Arriving, Value Investors Try for a Comeback
description: After years of lagging performance, practitioners of an old approach to investing are hoping their time is nigh.
content: Value investors have had a tough decade, with growth stocks stealing the investing show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Karan Deep Singh
title: A Mix of Pride and Doubts as Modi Launches India’s Covid-19 Vaccine Drive
description: One of the world’s largest inoculation programs is set to begin on Saturday, but experts have questioned the data behind one of the country’s two vaccines — and patients don’t get to pick their shot.
content: PUNE, India — India on Friday was preparing to launch one of the most ambitious and complex nationwide campaigns in its history: the rollout of coronavirus vaccines to 1.3 billion people, an undertaking that will stretch from the perilous reaches of the Himalayas to the dense jungles of the country’s southern tip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: A Scoop About the Pentagon Papers, 50 Years Later
description: A former Times reporter obtained the answer to a major question involving Neil Sheehan’s source, then had to keep it secret until last week.
content: Janny Scott was researching the life of Neil Sheehan, the New York Times reporter who broke the news of the Pentagon Papers in 1971, when she noticed a gaping, unanswered question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: TikTok Is Poised to Outlast Trump, and to Test Biden
description: It is unclear how the president-elect will approach the Chinese tech industry.
content: TikTok is about to outlast President Trump. Now, the company could become an early test of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s stance toward Chinese tech companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monique El-Faizy
title: Lockdown Was Our Breaking Point
description: We needed to marry for our relationship to survive. But “le confinement” was too much.
content: Our two-year-old marriage was already struggling before the pandemic sent France into lockdown. Now here we were, stuck in our Paris apartment with my two teenage sons. “Le confinement,” as the French lyrically call it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Russeth
title: Kim Tschang-Yeul, 91, Dies; Painted Water Drops Swollen With Meaning
description: Hailing from South Korea, he became an international art star with luminous images informed by Eastern philosophy and the trauma of war.
content: SEOUL — Kim Tschang-Yeul, who devoted a half century to creating luminous paintings of water drops that are informed by the trauma of war and Eastern philosophy, died on Jan. 5 in Seoul, South Korea. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By JoAnna Novak
title: My Grandfather Was a Good Cop. Or Was He?
description: I idolized him and his larger-than-life role in law enforcement. It’s more complicated now.
content: When my son crawls into my closet, he finds my grandfather’s police star. He flips open the heavy leather billfold. Etched into gold metal are the words “Chief, Stickney, Illinois.” When he moves onto another toy, I lift the suede protecting the star and slide out the ID card. There’s my grandfather’s signature, his cursive E, blue ink that still looks wet: Edward — a name I’ve passed on to my son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Repnikova
title: No, the Chaos in America Is Not a Gift to China and Russia
description: Autocrats around the world won’t gain from the United States’ pain.
content: Is the political disarray in the United States really “a godsend for America’s critics” or a “propaganda coup” for them? Is Chris Coons, a Democratic senator from Delaware, correct to warn that the crisis of American democracy “feeds into the playbooks of authoritarian leaders around the world?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas and Abby Goodnough
title: Trump health officials scramble to clarify confusing statements about how vaccines will be released to states.
description: Confusion ensued after an announcement prompted several states to assume that they would get an influx of new doses that could be used to vaccinate new people.
content: When the federal government announced Tuesday that it was releasing a stockpile of vaccine doses, some state health officials expected to get a boost in their weekly shipments to help address soaring demand for the vaccines as the pandemic rages out of control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Kyrie Irving Fined $50,000 for Attending Indoor Party
description: Irving, the star Nets guard, was found to have violated the N.B.A.’s coronavirus health and safety protocols that bar players from attending indoor social gatherings of 15 or more people.
content: The N.B.A. has fined Nets guard Kyrie Irving $50,000 for violating the league’s health and safety protocols after a video emerged that seemed to show Irving maskless at a family birthday party last weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Merkel’s Party to Choose New Leader, and Possible Successor as Chancellor
description: After nearly a year of jockeying, no clear front-runner has emerged to lead Germany’s Christian Democratic Union. Three men are vying for delegates’ votes this weekend.
content: BERLIN — Germany’s largest political party will choose a new leader on Saturday, with the winner well positioned to succeed Angela Merkel as the next chancellor of Europe’s leading economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: In Fleurie, Looking Beyond the Clichés of Beaujolais
description: In this esteemed cru of Beaujolais, the descriptions roll out reflexively: It’s floral, it’s soft, it’s easy. The truth is in the drinking.
content: In the years since Wine School began in 2014, we’ve taken a few dives into Beaujolais. Now it’s time for another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Virginia Sole-Smith
title: Should You Worry About Your Kid’s Pandemic Weight Gain?
description: Think of body changes as something to be curious about, not a problem to be solved.
content: Last spring, scientists predicted that the Covid-19 pandemic might contribute to a rise in children’s body weight, because of school closures and families hunkering down with comfort foods, lacking access to healthful meal options and exercising less. Yet while we know that childhood hunger has risen precipitously during the pandemic, we don’t have much data on whether children’s body sizes have changed in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Jim Rutenberg
title: A Republican senator from Oklahoma apologizes to Black constituents for seeking to disenfranchise them.
description: Senator James Lankford said in a letter that he had never intended to “diminish the voice of any Black American” by questioning the election results. Still, he added, “I should have recognized how what I said and what I did could be interpreted by many of you.”
content: Senator James Lankford, an Oklahoma Republican who spent weeks trying to reverse the results of the presidential election before changing his mind at the last moment, apologized on Thursday to Black constituents who felt he had attacked their right to vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Biden Appoints Former C.I.A. Deputy to Return to Job
description: The former agency official, David Cohen, is seen as a potential successor to the nominee to run the C.I.A.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. tapped David S. Cohen to return as deputy head of the C.I.A., placing an official who knows the agency well alongside the veteran diplomat he chose to lead it, the Biden transition team announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: A Data-Driven Courtship Leads to a Rooftop Wedding
description: Nicole Woon and Jeffrey Chheng had a first date at a Seattle gelato parlor, their second at a sushi restaurant. Since then, a spreadsheet documents their relationship, meal by meal.
content: The spreadsheet that Nicole Alison Woon and Jeffrey Ryan Chheng use to record the restaurants they’ve patronized in Seattle, nearly over 500 and counting, can be read as an oblique diary of the couple’s developing relationship. It contains Umi Sake House, the sushi spot where Ms. Woon and Mr. Chheng had their second date; RN74, a Valentine’s Day tradition every year since they began dating in 2017; and Sushi Kashiba, a birthday favorite of Ms. Woon’s and a place that evokes their time traveling in Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: What Comes Next
description: It was a big news week. Here are three takeaways to offer some clarity amid the chaos.
content: Hey everyone, happy Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: James Comey and Truth in Government
description: Joe Klein talks about Comey’s “Saving Justice,” and Elisabeth Egan discusses Peter Ho Davies’s “A Lie Someone Told You About Yourself.”
content: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conrad de Aenlle
title: The Pros and Cons of Funds That Mute the Ups and Downs
description: Various types of exchange-traded funds aim to reduce stock market volatility; some work well, but there may be better ways to smooth returns
content: If the exaggerated swings of the stock market are getting you down, cheer up. An expanding array of exchange-traded funds and other tools can limit volatility — for a price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A Surprising Instant Connection
description: Their match on Tinder didn’t reveal how similar the backgrounds of Rohini Pragasam and Chris Walton were. But they soon learned during their first date at a Japanese restaurant.
content: When Rohini Pragasam and Chris Walton met for a first date in April 2018 at a Japanese restaurant in Manhattan, each had arrived in anticipation of impressing the other with knowledge of all-things Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Hounded by Wildfires, Californians Rethink Their Willingness to Rebuild
description: In the aftermath, some people are deciding to just begin new lives elsewhere. The pandemic and longstanding housing problems haven’t made the choices any easier.
content: The day Paradise burned, Aaron Singer was a skeptic. Then he saw the flames in his rearview mirror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: Speed Swiping Right to a Warm, Winning Smile
description: Rachel Heyman spent an evening bingeing on Tinder and reality TV when Adam Joseph’s picture caught her eye.
content: Rachel Jennifer Heyman did some quick-fire swiping on the Tinder dating app at her apartment in Manhattan one Saturday evening in January 2019 with her friend over  glasses of wine, a variety of Trader Joe’s appetizers and reality TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Tom Lankford, 85, Dies; Southern Journalist With Divided Loyalties
description: He took memorable photographs of the civil rights movement for The Birmingham News. But behind the scenes he was building dubious relationships with law enforcement.
content: Tom Lankford, who as a reporter for The Birmingham News took some of the most memorable photos of the civil rights era even as he worked hand in glove with the city’s police department and the F.B.I., sometimes landing scoops in exchange for things like wiretapping members of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s family, died on Dec. 31 in a hospital in Gadsden, Ala., about 50 miles northeast of Birmingham. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Eileen Sullivan and Eric Schmitt
title: New Warnings of Violence as Security Tightens for Inauguration
description: Commercial airlines have tracked an increase in checked weapons, and federal law enforcement raised fresh alarms about extremist plots.
content: WASHINGTON — Law enforcement officials are vetting hundreds of potential airplane passengers and beefing up airport security as officials amplify warnings of violence before the presidential inauguration from extremists emboldened by the Capitol attack last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How the Medical Director of a Nonprofit Spends His Sundays
description: After clients and church duties, Dr. David Collymore might sneak in a game of Ms. Pac-Man.
content: “I tell people I’m a man with multiple callings,” said Dr. David Collymore, who is the medical director of a large social services organization but also a man of the cloth. “Medicine is one, church is another.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: He Brought Moynihan Train Hall to Life, but Didn’t Live to See It
description: Many credit Michael Evans with turning the vision for the hall at Penn Station into a reality. Before it opened, he took his own life.
content: When the Moynihan Train Hall was unveiled to the public this month, it was hailed as one of New York’s most important public works projects in recent memory, a symbol of the city’s resilience through one of its darkest years. New Yorkers marveled at the acre of glass splashed across its 92-foot-tall atrium and the century-old steel trusses holding the large skylight in place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian J. O'Connor

The superfast weapons, experts say, lend themselves to surprise attacks.

With nothing to look forward to but lockdown fatigue, lukewarm take-out and more isolation, the spirit of making things has soured. author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘Outside the Wire’ Review: At War With the Robots
description: This Netflix film starring Anthony Mackie is neither curious nor bold in the ways it depicts a sentient robotic revolt.
content: The director Mikael Hafstrom’s “Outside the Wire,” the latest Netflix combat film set in an exotic location, offers empty-calorie action in a less than fulfilling, Cold War-inspired robotic revolt narrative. The film’s redundant intertitles — several characters repeat the same information later — explain the outbreak of a civil war taking place in the year 2036 in Eastern Europe. U.S. troops, with the assistance of robotic soldiers called Gumps, serve as peacekeepers against the region’s ruthless criminal warlord Viktor Koval (Pilou Asbaek). Harp (Damson Idris), a dispassionate drone pilot, is ordered to the war zone as punishment after his cold calculation led to the deaths of two Marines. Paired with a top-secret android, Leo (Anthony Mackie), as his superior officer, he embarks on a mission to stop Koval from obtaining nuclear weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: After a Few Dates, They Traveled to the Other Side of the World
description: Jeffrey Basting, a government refugee officer, was on a two-month assignment in New Orleans when he met Hallie Dietsch. She didn’t think that their relationship could last.
content: Imagine this: In the wee hours one morning, during a vacation in Southeast Asia, you set off with a guide to hike to the top of Mount Merapi, a volcano in Indonesia. After a grueling, miles-long plod, you arrive at the top, just in time for sunrise. You find the perfect spot to sit. As you gaze across the fiery sky, you can sense the earth breathing beneath you. Then, all of a sudden, you hear a loud whirring from above. You look up. You see the belly of something mechanical. With horror, you realize that a Canadian guy in another hiking party has piloted his drone directly above your head. And just like that, your moment of transcendence has been snuffed out, 21st century style.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Ireland, Lifting a Veil of Prejudice Against Mixed-Race Children

content: While helping her mother work merchandise tables at some of Dublin’s most respected venues, Jess Kavanagh first got a taste for the music scene. title: Getting Rid of Stuff

content: Welcome. Before weekdays and weekends were indistinguishable, we left the house. Now, we’re inside, many of us, most of time. With the same people and pets, or on our own; the same routines and rooms; and, everywhere we turn, the same stuff, so much stuff. What used to be décor is now clutter. What once was cozy is now claustrophobic. This is when I turn to The Annoying Bag.

content: AMNESTY, by Aravind Adiga. (Scribner, 272 pp., $17.) The “driving force” of this “thriller-like” novel by the Booker Prize-winning Indian-Australian author of “The White Tiger” is an unsolved murder about which its undocumented protagonist has information. title: What to Cook This Weekend

content: Two weeks into 2021 and circus music’s playing everywhere. You’d be forgiven if all you wanted to do this weekend was cook a crispy Parmesan roast chicken with lemon (above), stretch it into sandwiches the next day, then make the bones into a nice stock for soup. You could pair the chicken with a bowl of buttered pasta and some sautéed spinach, then escape into the world of a book for a while — I’m in Beartown, myself, with Fredrik Backman’s “Us Against You.” These are hard days we’re going through. There’s much to be said for the simplicity of a roasted chicken.

author: By Stephen Kearse
title: The Essential Octavia Butler
description: She created vivid new worlds to reveal truths about our own. Here’s where to start with her books.
content: Octavia Butler walked a singular path. A writer from her poverty-stricken childhood to her death in 2006 at the age of 58, she committed her life to turning speculative fiction into a home for Black expression. In her hands, the genre felt capacious and infinite. “I wrote myself in,” she told The New York Times in 2000.
